name: Chef Mark's Seafood Gumbo
description: A lighter version of traditional seafood gumbo with a perfect dark roux and fresh Gulf shrimp, crab, and oysters
healthNotes: Uses lighter oil-to-flour ratio than traditional gumbo. Rich in protein and omega-3s.
culturalSignificance: Gumbo is the soul of Louisiana cooking, representing the melting pot of French, African, Spanish, and Native American influences.
chefNotes: The key is patience with the roux - don't rush it. A dark chocolate color gives the best flavor.

name: Blackened Redfish with Herb Butter
description: Paul Prudhomme's legendary technique with Chef Mark's healthy twist - perfectly spiced and seared fish
healthNotes: Uses olive oil instead of butter for blackening. Rich in protein and heart-healthy fats.
culturalSignificance: Blackening technique was invented in New Orleans and became a worldwide sensation in the 1980s.
chefNotes: Make sure your pan is screaming hot and your kitchen is well-ventilated. The smoke is part of the magic.

name: Shrimp and Andouille Étouffée
description: Smothered shrimp and spicy sausage in a rich, tomato-free Cajun gravy over fluffy rice
healthNotes: Lighter roux than traditional. High protein from shrimp. Can use turkey andouille for less fat.
culturalSignificance: Étouffée means 'smothered' in French - a cooking method that creates incredible depth of flavor.
chefNotes: Don't overcook the shrimp - they should be just pink and tender. Add them at the very end.

name: Oysters Rockefeller
description: The legendary Antoine's dish with Chef Mark's lightened spinach and herb topping
healthNotes: Uses olive oil instead of butter. Packed with minerals from oysters. High in iron and zinc.
culturalSignificance: Created at Antoine's Restaurant in 1899, named after John D. Rockefeller due to its richness.
chefNotes: Fresh herbs are non-negotiable here. The combination creates a uniquely New Orleans flavor.

name: Red Beans and Rice
description: Monday's traditional dish made with love, andouille, and the perfect creamy texture
ingredients: Hot sauce and green onions for garnish
healthNotes: High protein and fiber from beans. Can use turkey sausage for lighter version.
culturalSignificance: Traditionally made on Mondays using Sunday's leftover ham bone. A New Orleans institution.
chefNotes: The longer you cook it, the better. Some beans should break down to create that signature creaminess.

name: Crawfish Étouffée
description: The most beloved Louisiana dish - sweet crawfish tails in a blonde roux-based gravy
ingredients: 2 lbs Louisiana crawfish tails with fat
healthNotes: Crawfish are low in fat and calories, high in protein. The fat adds flavor but use sparingly.
culturalSignificance: Crawfish season (February-June) is sacred in Louisiana. This is the ultimate celebration dish.
chefNotes: The yellow crawfish fat is liquid gold - it's where all the flavor lives. Don't waste a drop.

name: BBQ Shrimp New Orleans Style
description: Not barbecued at all - jumbo shrimp in a buttery, peppery, Worcestershire sauce
ingredients: 2 lbs jumbo shrimp, heads-on if possible
French bread for soaking up sauce
healthNotes: Uses more olive oil, less butter than traditional. Shrimp are excellent protein source.
culturalSignificance: Popularized by Pascal's Manale in the 1950s. A New Orleans obsession ever since.
chefNotes: Don't peel the shrimp! The shells add flavor and protect the meat. Eat with your hands and lots of bread.

name: Chicken and Sausage Gumbo
description: The everyday hero gumbo - rich dark roux, tender chicken, spicy andouille
ingredients: Cooked rice and filé powder for serving
healthNotes: Remove chicken skin before cooking for less fat. High protein, very filling.
culturalSignificance: The most common gumbo made in Louisiana homes. Often prepared for Sunday dinners and gatherings.
chefNotes: A brick-red roux is your goal. Stir constantly and have patience. This is a labor of love.
